The pivotal role of CO2 hydrogenation in mitigating emissions and generating value-added fuels and chemicals underscores the significance of catalysts in achieving high efficiency in this process. The influence of metal-metal oxide interactions on catalyst performance has been widely acknowledged. In this study, Co-metal oxide interaction is tailored by calcining a mixed CoAl hydroxide (i.e., CoAl layered double hydroxide and Al hydroxide) at different temperatures and subsequently explored its impact on CO2 hydrogenation. The findings reveal that a moderate Co-metal oxide interaction results in a balanced Co0-Co2+ synergy. This synergy, in turn, facilitates CO2 conversion through a HCOO route at the Co0-Co2+ interface, leading to elevated turnover frequencies for CO2 conversion and the production of methane with a selectivity surpassing 98%, while methanol and ethanol are generated as minor byproducts. Graphical Abstract Keywords CO2 hydrogenation Cobalt Synergy Interaction Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The escalating CO2 emissions resulting from the excessive use of fossil fuels have led to global warming, posing a threat to sustainable human development. To address this issue, Carbon Capture and Utilization (CCU) emerges as a pivotal strategy to reduce CO2 emissions. CCU technologies facilitate the conversion of CO2 into fuels and chemicals through CO2 hydrogenation. The catalysts employed in this process play a crucial role in tailoring the formation of various products [1–6]. Among the diverse catalysts available, Co-based catalysts stand out for their versatility in enabling the formation of a range of products, including methane, olefins, long-chain hydrocarbons, methanol, and higher alcohols [7–14]. This versatility is attributed to the presence of various cobalt species, such as Co0, CoO, Coδ+, and Co2C, and the synergy between them [12–17]. Amongst, the synergistic effect of Co0-Co2+ in CO2 hydrogenation has been substantiated in our prior research [18]. Generally, metal-oxide (support) interactions play a significant role in the catalytic conversion of CO2 [19–21]. The interplay between the supporting matrix and metal nanoparticles influences catalysis, encompassing phenomena like charge transfer, interfacial perimeter, nanoparticle morphology, chemical composition, and strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) [22]. These interactions serve as a crucial strategy for tailoring surface Co species and the synergy between them, thereby influencing the activity and selectivity of Co-based catalysts in CO2 hydrogenation. Tailoring the Co-support interaction provides a means to control the Co surface species. The formation of Co metal during reduction depends on the specific support and its interaction with Co metal [23]. For example, when using supports like SiO2, Al2O3, Nb2O5, TiO2, and MgO, Co-support compounds such as Co-silicate, Co-aluminate, Co-niobate, Co-titanate, and Co-magnesia solid solutions can be formed [23–26]. However, the creation of these Co-support species might negatively impact the catalytic performance of the Co metal due to their challenging reducibility [23]. Moreover, customizing the interaction between Co and oxide has proven effective in tailoring CO2 hydrogenation reactions. Silica serves a dual role as both a support and ligand, modifying Co species through CoOSiOn linkages. A recent study by Belthle et. al suggests that the formation of strongly interacting, scarcely reducible Co−O−SiOn or Co silicate species over metallic Co reduces CO2 hydrogenation activity but enhances selectivity towards oxygenates [27]. Another study indicates that the Co−O−SiOn interaction results in the coexistence of Co and CoO phases, and a balance between these phases on catalysts is crucial for methanol production [10]. Parastaev et al. have also manipulated the metal–oxide interaction in ceria–zirconia-supported Co catalysts by adjusting Co loading and reduction temperature [28]. Through the partial reduction of Co particles at a lower temperature, the catalysts exhibit Co oxide covered with very small metallic clusters, leading to unusually high catalytic activity of small (3 nm) Co/Co(II) oxide nanoparticles. Additional study by Wang et. al reveals that a strong interaction between Co species and SBA-15 support stabilizes CoO under CO2 hydrogenation conditions, shifting the product from methane over Co0 to CO over CoO [29]. In contrast, Co-ceria interactions enhance the reducibility of Co/CeO2, resulting in improved catalytic performance and up to 100% conversion of CO2 to methane [30]. Furthermore, the Co-oxide interface plays a crucial role in CO2 hydrogenation reactions. It is suggested that CoO forms a catalytically active and unique interface with TiO2, enhancing CO2 hydrogenation activity [31]. Similarly, in metallic Co/Mn(II)O nanoparticle that forms from the initial MnCo2O4 spinel structure, the Co/MnO interface contributes to methane production through a ‘formate route’ [32]. Layered double hydroxides (LDHs) or hydrotalcites, with their unique structure, emerge as promising materials for CO2 capturing and utilization. In general, LDH precursors offer advantages such as the uniform distribution of active metal cations and strong metal-metal oxide (support) interactions during calcination, preventing sintering of metal particles and enhancing catalytic stability [33]. While LDH-derived CoAl based catalysts have been applied in CO2 hydrogenation [8,9,34], the impact of Co-metal oxide interaction has remained unexplored yet. In this work, CoAl LDH containing mixed hydroxides were synthesized by coprecipitation as the precursor, and the Co-metal oxide interaction is specifically tailored by manipulating the calcination temperature. Opting for a moderate calcination temperature resulted in a balanced Co-metal oxide interaction, yielding a moderate Co0-Co2+ synergy. This synergistic effect, in turn, facilitate CO2 conversion through a HCOO route at the Co0-Co2+ interface, leading to increased turnover frequencies (TOFs) for CO2 conversion to methane as the main product (>98% selectivity), with methanol and ethanol as the minor product. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of catalysts CoAl LDH containing mixed hydroxides were synthesized via a co-precipitation method adapted from Ref [35,36]. Briefly, two precursor solutions were prepared: Solution A containing 0.06 M each of Al(NO3)3 and Co(NO3)2 and Solution B containing 0.40 M NaOH and 0.12 M Na2CO3. These solutions were added dropwise to an ice-cooled beaker under constant stirring, maintaining the pH at 8.5 throughout the mixing process. The resulting suspension was filtered, and the precipitate was washed thoroughly with deionized water to remove impurities. After drying at 100 °C, the mixed CoAl hydroxide precursor was subjected to air calcination at various temperatures (300–800 °C) for 3 h, followed by H2 reduction at 650 °C for 3 h (when applicable). The resulting catalysts were named CoAl-CX-R, where C denotes calcination, and X denotes calcination temperature (X = none if not calcined), and R denotes reduction (omitted if not reduced). 2.2 Characterization of catalysts The crystal structures of the samples were investigated using X-ray diffraction (XRD) on a SmartLab diffractometer equipped with a Cu Kα radiation source (λ = 1.5406 Å, 40 kV, 40 mA). Crystallite sizes were calculated using the Scherrer equation. Thermal behavior was assessed by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) on a Thermogravimetric Analyzer (TGA 2050, TA Instruments). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was performed on a Kratos Axis Supra spectrometer, with binding energies calibrated using the Al 2p peak at 74.6 eV as a reference. Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) using a Nicolet 870 instrument was employed to characterize chemical bonds present in the catalysts. N2 adsorption isotherms at 77 K were measured using a Micromeritics 2460 instrument. The samples were subjected to degassing at 200 °C prior to N2 physisorption. Co and Al concentrations were determined by inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) on a Varian 720ES instrument. The morphology of the calcined samples was observed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) on a ZEISS Sigma 500 instrument equipped with a field emission source. Post-reduction/spent catalysts’ transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were captured with an FEI Talos F200S field emission transmission electron microscope. H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR), H2 temperature-programmed desorption (H2-TPD), and CO2 temperature-programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) experiments were conducted on a VDSorb-9Xi chemisorption analyzer following the procedure described in Ref [18]. Briefly, pre-dried catalysts (150 °C, 1 h, Ar) underwent H2-TPR in 10% H2/Ar (30 mL/min) at 10 °C /min (70–800 °C, 10 min hold). For H2-TPD analysis, the catalysts were reduced in H2 at 650 °C for 3 h in advance. After cooling to 100 °C (Ar, 0.5 h), the catalysts were exposed to 10% H2/Ar (30 mL/min) at 100 °C for 1 h to adsorb H2. Subsequent Ar purging (1 h) was followed by H2 desorption at 10 °C/min (100–800 °C, 50 min hold). For CO2-TPD, catalysts were reduced at 650 °C for 3 h and cooled to 50 °C (Ar, 1 h). CO2 adsorption occurred at 50 °C for 1 h in 5% CO2/He (30 mL/min), followed by He purging (1 h) and CO2 desorption at 10 °C/min (50–800 °C, 50 min hold). A thermal conductivity detector monitored the gas stream composition. Eqs. 1–3 were used to calculate reduction degree, dispersion, and the fraction of surface-exposed and reduced Co, (1) RD = n Co , red n Co , to t (2) D = n Co , red , surf n Co , red (3) F Co , s , r = n Co , red , surf n Co , tot where RD (%) represents the degree of reduction, while D (%) denotes the dispersion. The total molar quantity of Co in the catalysts, designated as n Co,tot (μmol), is determined from the overall H2 consumption observed during H2-TPR measurement. Furthermore, the molar number of reduced Co, termed n Co,red (μmmol), is ascertained from the H2 consumption measured up to 650 °C during H2-TPR. Notably, In the quantification of n Co,tot and n Co,red for CoAl-C300/400/500, a mixture of Co3O4, CoO, and CoAl2O4 was considered. The reduction peaks observed below approximately 450 °C are attributed to the reduction of Co3O4 to metallic cobalt (Co0), where the consumption of 1 mol of H2 results in the formation of 3/4 mol of Co0. Conversely, the peaks above 450 °C are attributed to the reduction of CoO and CoAl2O4 to Co0, with 1 mol of H2 producing 1 mol of Co0. For catalysts calcined at temperatures exceeding 600 °C, the reduction peaks correspond to the reduction of CoO and CoAl2O4 to Co0. Additionally, the quantity of Co that is not only reduced but also accessible on the surface, referred to as n Co,red,surf (μmmol), is calculated from the volume of chemisorbed H2, presupposing dissociative adsorption of H2. Finally, F Co , s , r (%) signifies the proportion of Co that is both surface-exposed and reduced. 2.3 Catalytic tests CO2 hydrogenation experiments followed the procedure described in our previous work [18]. Briefly, a 50 mL batch reactor with a magnetic stirrer and Teflon lining was charged with 50 mg of pre-reduced catalyst and 15 mL of water. The autoclave was then purged three times with 1 MPa CO2 to remove air, followed by the addition of another 1 MPa CO2 and 3 MPa H2. The reaction mixture was heated to 180 °C and stirred at 350 rpm for 1 h. After cooling in an ice bath, the gaseous products were collected and analyzed offline using an Agilent 8890 GC system equipped with a thermal conductivity detector, HayeSep Q and MolSleve 5A columns. CH4 concentrations were determined by the external standard method, and their total amounts were calculated using the ideal gas law. The liquid phase was analyzed using an Agilent 8860 GC system with a flame ionization detector and an HP-Innowax column, with tetrahydrofuran as the internal standard. Eqs. 4, 5 and 6, (4) Y i = n i t × m cat (5) TOF i = n i t × n Co , red , surf (6) S i = Y i Y CH 4 + Y MeOH + Y EtOH were used to calculate the yields of methanol, ethanol, and methane, the turnover frequencies, as well as the selectivities. Here Y i (μmol/g/h, i stands for methanol, ethanol, or methane) is the yield of product i, n i (μmol, carbon based) is the number of moles of product i, t (h) is the reaction time, and m cat (g) is the catalyst mass used. TOF i (/h) denotes the Turnover Frequency (TOF) of product i, and the total TOF of CO2 conversion is the sum of TOF MEOH, TOF ETOH, and TOF CH4. S i (%) represents the selectivity to product i. The spent catalyst can be collected through filtration, followed by washing and drying, prior to characterization. As we used various catalysts (precipitated, calcined, reduced, and used) for different characterization methods and tests, we have provided this information in Table S1. 3 Results and discussion The synthesis of the catalysts involved coprecipitation of Co and Al, followed by calcination at elevated temperature and reduction in H2 at 650 °C. The as-precipitated, calcined, and reduced catalysts were characterized by various technique. Notably, the characterization and catalytic results of the catalyst calcined at 400 °C, CoAl-C400(-R), have been reported in our previous paper, Ref. [18], discussing the effects of precipitation pH and reduction temperature. The thermal decomposition of the as-precipitated material in pure O2 was investigated by TG analysis, and the TG and DTG curves are presented in Fig. 1. The mass loss profile is consistent with that of CoAl-CO3 2− LDH in the literature [37–40]. The mass loss occurs mainly below 400 °C, resulting in a total mass loss of 33% and three stages of mass loss were observed. The first stage (peaking at 82 °C) corresponds to the release of physically adsorbed water. The second stage (peaking at 157 °C) is attributed to the removal of interlayer water molecules and CO2 (from intercalated CO3 2−) from the LDH structure and Al hydroxide. The third stage (peaking at 206 °C) is due to the thermal decomposition of the brucite-like layers through the elimination of OH groups as water or partial dehydroxylation of aluminum hydroxide. Above 400 °C, no significant mass loss was detected. Therefore, by varying the calcination temperature of the dried precursor, different structures of the catalysts could be obtained. Compositions of the as-precipitated and calcined catalysts were analyzed using ICP-OES and Table 1 summarizes the concentration of Co and Al in the prepared catalysts. The Co/Al molar ratio is close to 1 for all the materials, similar to the nominal value used during the synthesis. Moreover, N2-physisorption measurements were also performed to study textural properties of the as-precipitated and calcined catalysts and Figure S1 displays the obtained adsorption-desorption isotherms. The obtained isotherms exhibit H3 type hysteresis loops, indicating the presence of wedge-shaped pores created by packed plate-like particles or the presence of macropores [41]. Table 1 also presents the BET specific surface area and pore volume of the as-precipitated and calcined catalysts. The as-precipitated catalyst has a specific surface area of 127 m2/g. As the catalysts undergo degassing at 200 °C before conducting N2 physisorption, the specific surface area of the precipitated catalysts should be evaluated with respect to this temperature. The specific surface area first increases and then decreases with an increase in calcination temperature. The highest specific surface area of 188 m2/g is obtained for CoAl-C400, while the lowest specific surface area of 31 m2/g is obtained for CoAl-C800. The decrease in specific surface area at high temperature is ascribed to the formation of well-defined spinel phases [39]. The pore volume of the as-precipitated catalyst is 0.41 m3/g. The pore volume ranges from 0.49 to 0.58 m3/g for the catalysts calcined at 300–700 °C, but it drops dramatically to 0.01 m3/g for CoAl-C800, which might be related to the increased crystallite size at this temperature, as indicated by XRD results. Moreover, the obtained SEM images (Figure S2) indicate that calcination at high temperature leads to a morphology change from plate-like to sphere-like particles. FT-IR spectra of the as-precipitated and calcined catalysts were collected to study the existing chemical bonds in the prepared catalysts ( Fig. 2). A broad absorption band around 3500 /cm is attributed to the O–H stretching vibrations of the hydroxyl groups in the LDH layers, Al hydroxide, and on the surface of spinel [37,42–45]. The absorption bands at 1377 and 794 /cm are assigned to the stretching and bending modes of CO3 2−, respectively. Besides, the bands at 662 and 570 /cm correspond to the stretching and bending modes of metal–oxygen bonds (Co–O and Al–O) vibrations [37,42,43]. The absorbance ratio of O–H (at 3500 /cm) to metal–oxygen (at 675 /cm) was calculated for each catalyst. The ratio decreases from 0.73 to 0.15 with the increase of calcination temperature from 300 to 800 °C, indicating a decrease in the amount of OH groups in the catalysts. Besides, absorbance of the CO3 2− bands also decrease significantly. These phenomena are related to the decomposition of LDH and Al hydroxide structure and the formation of mixed oxide and spinel-type oxide after calcination [46]. The XRD analysis ( Fig. 3) of the as-precipitated and calcined catalysts reveal their crystalline structures. As can be seen, the as precipitated catalyst possess relatively low signal to noise ratio, with broadened peaks, and some weak peaks (12.1°[003], 23.3°[006], 34.8°[009]) are consistent with the CoAl-CO3 2− LDH structure [47–49], suggesting that the as precipitated material may consist amorphous Al hydroxide with CoAL LDH. However, due to the amorphous nature of the material, diffraction peaks at 12°, 24°, and 36° are masked. Upon calcination, the LDH structure and Al hydroxide transform into spinel oxides (i.e., Co3O4, Co2AlO4, CoAl2O4). As the calcination temperature increases, the XRD peaks become more distinct indicating that the crystallinity and the crystallite size of the catalysts increase. The crystallite size based on the (131) peak at 36.77° was estimated by the Scherrer equation and found to increase from 3.7 to 32.7 nm as the calcination temperature increases from 300 to 800 °C, in agreement with the results reported by Ulibarri et. al [39]. The relative intensity ratios of different peaks were also calculated to evaluate the preferred orientation of the catalysts. For example, the ratio of the (044) peak at 65.04° to the (131) peak at 36.77° first increases and then decreases with increasing calcination temperature, reaching a maximum of 0.59 at 400 °C, while the ratio of the (040) peak to the (131) peak decreases continuously from 0.41 to 0.18 as the calcination temperature increases from 300 to 800 °C. These results suggest that the calcination temperature affects both the crystallite size and the exposure of various crystal facets of the prepared catalysts. The cation distribution in the spinel crystal lattice affects the ratios of the peak intensity, which may vary in different ways. For example, in a CoNbyFe2-yO4 (0.00≤y≤0.08) spinel, the (040)/(044) intensity ratio decreases steadily as y increases, while the (242)/(040) intensity ratio first increases and then decreases [50]. In this work, we obtained catalysts with different calcination temperatures. We found that the (040)/(131) intensity ratio decreases steadily and the (044)/(131) intensity ratio increases and then decreases, reaching a maximum at 400 °C. This may be due to the change in the cation distribution caused by the structural evolution from amorphous to crystalline Co3O4/Co2AlO4/CoAl2O4 as the calcination temperature increased [51]. Furthermore, the Co oxidation states of both as-precipitated and calcined catalysts were examined using XPS, and Fig. 4 illustrates the obtained Co 2p spectra. For the as-precipitated catalysts, four sets of peaks corresponding to the main Co3+ peaks, Co3+ satellite peaks, Co2+ main peaks, and Co2+ satellite peaks are observed. This suggests the coexistence of Co2+ and Co3+ in the mixed CoAl hydroxide precursor, consistent with previous research results [52,53]. After calcination, these peaks persist, attributed to the presence of Co2+ and Co3+ in the Co3O4, Co2AlO4, and CoAl2O4 structures. Notably, the fraction of Co2+ in the as-precipitated catalyst is 82.5%, while after calcination, this value decreases to 75.2%–76.9% due to the oxidation of Co2+ to Co3+ during the calcination step. Reducibility of the as-precipitated and calcined catalysts was also investigated using H2-TPR. As depicted in Fig. 5a, the as precipitated catalyst shows a broad peak (400–800 °C), which is attributed to the CO2 release from the CoAl-CO3 2− LDH decomposition and the H2 consumption by reduction of the metal oxides. Besides, the calcined catalysts exhibit two sets of peaks, corresponding to the reduction of Co3O4 to CoO and then to Co0 at low temperatures (<400 °C for CoAl-C300), and the reduction of CoAl oxide at high temperatures (400–800 °C) [54,55]. The low-temperature peaks shift to higher temperatures and merge with the high-temperature peaks as the calcination temperature increase above 500 °C. A prominent peak at 800 °C is observed for the catalysts calcined at high temperatures, indicating the formation of strongly interacted Co-Al-O species, surface Co2+ ions with a high number of O–Al ligands [56]. In general, reduction peak temperature reflects the strength of metal-metal oxide interaction. As shown in Fig. 5b, the CoO to Co0 reduction peak temperature increases from 354 to 513 °C as the calcination temperature increases from 300 to 800 °C, suggesting stronger metal-metal oxide interaction. Moreover, the reduction degree of the catalysts decreases with increasing calcination temperature (Fig. 5b). A significant drop to 28% is observed for the catalyst calcined at 800 °C. This trend could be explained by enhanced strength of metal-metal oxide interaction [54]. Although employing a reduction temperature higher than that of calcination may obscure some features, the impact of the calcination temperature on the interactions between metal and metal oxide, as well as on the CO2 hydrogenation reaction, is still considerable. This assertion is corroborated by both TPR results and findings documented in the literature [54,57]. The catalysts’ ability to activate H2 and CO2 was evaluated by performing H2/CO2-TPD experiments. Fig. 6a shows the H2-TPD profiles of all reduced catalysts. Two sets of peaks are observed: the low-temperature ones (around 190 °C) and the high-temperature ones (around 800 °C). These peaks correspond to the weakly and strongly adsorbed H, respectively [58]. Interestingly, the weakly adsorbed peak shifts to higher temperature when the calcination temperature increases from uncalcined to a calcined catalyst at 400 °C, and then shifts to lower temperature when the calcination temperature increases further. A similar trend is also observed for the strongly adsorbed H peak. Moreover, the desorption amount decreases with increasing calcination temperature (Fig. 5b), indicating decreasing chemically active surface area. Fig. 6b shows the CO2-TPD profiles of all the reduced catalysts. A similar peak temperature shift phenomenon as of the H2-TPD profiles is exhibited. This suggests that a medium calcination temperature favors strong adsorption of H/CO2, due to the Co0 and Co2+ synergy [59,60]. The number of active sites on the catalysts’ surface was also quantified using H2-TPD, assuming that H2 dissociatively adsorbs on Co-based catalysts. Accordingly, the uncalcined catalysts have active sites of 569 μmol/gcat and this value increases to 775 μmol/gcat after calcination at 300 °C. However, further increasing the calcination temperature reduces the number of active sites, reaching a minimum of 212 μmol/gcat for the catalyst calcined at 800 °C. The decreasing number of active sites with increasing calcination temperature may be due to the decreasing BET specific surface area and the increasing size of crystallite [61]. The reduced catalyst, CoAl-C400-R650, was also characterized by XRD (Figure S3) and TEM (Figure S4). The XRD analysis demonstrates the presence of both Co0 and CoAl2O4 phases within the catalyst. This observation is further supported by TEM imaging, which reveals the distinct crystal facets corresponding to Co0 (111) and CoAl2O4 (131) facets [62,63]. Furthermore, post-reduction TEM images unveil a morphology characterized by particles anchored onto plate-like structures. The catalytic performance of catalysts calcined at different temperatures in CO2 hydrogenation is assessed using a batch reactor. Fig. 7 illustrates the catalytic results of the CO2 hydrogenation over the resulting catalysts, demonstrating the production of methane, methanol, and ethanol. The STYs for methane, methanol, and ethanol exhibit a volcano-type trend with increasing calcination temperature. Initially, both STYs and CO2 conversion rates rise with higher calcination temperatures, but temperatures exceeding 700 and 800 °C result in declining STYs. Notably, within the 300–600 °C calcination temperature range, STYs and CO2 conversion rates exhibit minimal fluctuations. The selectivity of all products remained relatively stable across the calcination temperature range. Methane selectivity ranges from 98.3% to 98.4%, MeOH from 1.3% to 1.5%, and EtOH from 0.23% to 0.30% in the investigated temperature range. As illustrated in Fig. 8, a correlation is established between STY MeOH, STY EtOH, and STY CH4. It is observed that STY MeOH and STY EtOH increase linearly with rising STY CH4 but plateau when STY CH4 is high. STY MeOH increases with higher STY EtOH, yet it plateaus when STY EtOH exceeds 70 µmol EtOH/gcat/h. Previous propositions suggested that CO2 hydrogenation over Co-based catalysts to produce methanol, ethanol, and methane involves an *HCOO intermediate (see Fig. 9). The *HCOO intermediate can be hydrogenated to form methanol or *CHx, which in turn can be further hydrogenated to produce methane. Alternatively, *CHx can couple with *HCOO to form *CH3CH2O species, followed by additional hydrogenation to yield ethanol. The shared intermediate *HCOO among the formation pathways of methanol, ethanol, and methane suggests competition, leading to the observed patterns with flattened or decreasing trends at higher values. To assess the impact of metal-metal oxide interaction on CO2 hydrogenation, TOFs were also calculated for CO2 conversion, methane, methanol, and ethanol formation. These TOFs were then correlated with the reduction peak temperature of CoO, serving as an indicator for the metal-metal oxide interaction. The resulting trend exhibits a volcano-shaped pattern as the reduction peak temperature increases ( Fig. 10), suggesting that an intermediate metal-metal oxide interaction promotes the conversion of CO2 to methane, methanol, and ethanol. Furthermore, as the calcination temperature increases from 300 to 800 °C, the catalyst displays fewer OH groups, accompanied by changes in crystallite size and the preferential exposure of crystal facets. The decreasing amount of OH groups and an increase in crystallite size indicates a stronger interaction between Co-metal oxide, transitioning from ionic interaction with OH to covalent interaction of Co/Al-O. With a strong metal-metal oxide interaction in the catalysts, the reduction process becomes more challenging. These alterations in turn affected the catalysts’ ability to activate H2 and CO2, influencing their activity in CO2 conversion. Previous reports highlighted that the fraction of reduced and surface-exposed Co (F Co,r,s) in the catalysts, representing Co0-Co2+ synergy, correlates with their performance in CO2 hydrogenation [18]. Eq. 7 defines F Co,r,s as the product of reduction degree (reflected by the Co0/(Co0 + Coδ+) ratio) and dispersion (influencing the Co0-CoAl2O4/Al oxide interface). This combined metric captures information on both the Co0/Coδ+ ratio and the Co0-CoAl2O4/Al oxide interface, providing a more holistic understanding of the Co0-Coδ+ synergy. Consequently, F Co,r,s exhibits a stronger correlation with the TOFs. (7) F Co , r , s = n Co , red , surf n Co , tot = n Co , red , surf n Co , red × n Co , red n Co , tot = Redection degree × Dispersion Accordingly, the TOFs for CO2 conversion and methanol/ethanol/methane formation demonstrates a volcano-shaped correlation with F Co,r,s, achieving maximum TOFs at moderate F Co,r,s, through HCOO route at the Co0-Co2+ interface [18]. This correlation persists across the catalysts calcined at various temperatures ( Fig. 11). Additionally, F Co,r,s shows a strong correlation with the reduction peak temperature ( Fig. 12), leading to the conclusion that the Co-metal oxide interaction shapes the Co0-Co2+ synergy, ultimately influencing the activation and conversion of H2 and CO2 to methanol/ethanol/methane. While reduction degree, solely reflecting the Co0/ Coδ+ ratio, fails to correlate with TOFs (Figure S5). The spent CoAl-C400-R650 catalyst was also characterized by XRD and TEM (Figs. S3 and S4). The XRD patterns reveal that post-CO2 hydrogenation, both Co0 and CoAl2O4 remain present, accompanied by the emergence of CoCO3 [64], likely formed due to CO2 interaction. The simultaneous presence of Co0 and CoAl2O4 is corroborated by HRTEM, which displays the respective crystal facets of (111) for Co0 and (131) for CoAl2O4. Nonetheless, accurately quantifying Co0 and Co2+ in the post CO2 hydrogenation catalyst presents a challenge, as the catalyst undergoes washing and drying prior to characterization, potentially inducing partial oxidation of Co0. Such oxidation could compromise the reliability of the stability results. The stability of the catalysts would be investigated in a continuous slurry reactor in our future research. 4 Conclusion The interaction between metal and metal oxide plays a pivotal role in catalysts’ activity. Herein, the effects of Co-Co/Al oxide interaction on CO2 hydrogenation were investigated. By calcining a mixed CoAl hydroxide precursor at elevated temperatures, OH groups are gradually eliminated, shifting the ionic interaction towards Co/Al-O covalent interaction. This intensified Co-metal oxide interaction is validated by H2-TPR. The strength of this interaction is directly linked to the fraction of reduced and surface-exposed Co, serving as an indicator for Co0-Co2+ synergy. Opting for a moderate calcination temperature results in a balanced Co-metal oxide interaction and, consequently, a moderate Co0-Co2+ synergy. This synergy at a moderate level enhances CO2 hydrogenation, particularly through a HCOO route at the Co0-Co2+ interface, ultimately yielding high TOFs with methane as the primary product (exceeding 98% selectivity), and methanol and ethanol as minor products. coredata.dc:description: The pivotal role of CO2 hydrogenation in mitigating emissions and generating value-added fuels and chemicals underscores the significance of catalysts in achieving high efficiency in this process. The influence of metal-metal oxide interactions on catalyst performance has been widely acknowledged. In this study, Co-metal oxide interaction is tailored by calcining a mixed CoAl hydroxide (i.e., CoAl layered double hydroxide and Al hydroxide) at different temperatures and subsequently explored its impact on CO2 hydrogenation. The findings reveal that a moderate Co-metal oxide interaction results in a balanced Co0-Co2+ synergy. This synergy, in turn, facilitates CO2 conversion through a HCOO route at the Co0-Co2+ interface, leading to elevated turnover frequencies for CO2 conversion and the production of methane with a selectivity surpassing 98%, while methanol and ethanol are generated as minor byproducts.
coredata.dc:title: CO2 hydrogenation over CoAl based catalysts: Effects of cobalt-metal oxide interaction
